title: Research Atlas
summary: A static-first platform of prompts, workflows, and guides that helps researchers run AI-assisted projects with stronger rigor and verification.
overview: Research Atlas is a research-methods platform I built to make AI-assisted academic work more structured and trustworthy. Instead of treating prompting as isolated chat tricks, the product organizes reusable prompts, stage-based workflows, and method guides across the research lifecycle. The goal is simple: help researchers move faster without sacrificing quality, provenance, or interpretability.
myRole: I designed and built the project end to end: information architecture, taxonomy, content model, UX, and frontend implementation. I also wrote and curated core methodological content, including reproducible NotebookLM workflows, verification guardrails, and practical prompts for scoping, extraction, synthesis, and review. On the technical side, I implemented static rendering, route-level SEO, and a content-first pipeline so updates can ship quickly without backend complexity.

sections.title: What I Built
content: A static-first research platform with dedicated Library, Workflows, and Guides modules.
A unified taxonomy connecting prompt assets to research stages (design, data QC, analysis, interpretation, writing, and review).
A NotebookLM workflow framework with reproducibility conventions, quality-control gates, and citation verification steps.
Guide content that translates abstract AI advice into operational SOP-style procedures for real research teams.
SEO and discoverability foundations, including canonical routes, pre-rendering, and structured metadata.

sections.title: Why It Matters
sections.content: Most AI tooling in research focuses on speed but under-specifies reliability. I built Research Atlas to close that gap by pairing practical productivity with explicit verification rules. The result is a resource researchers can use for daily execution, teaching, and lab standardization.

outcomes: Published a live methodology platform at researchatlas.info with production-ready prompt and workflow content.
Established a reusable schema for scaling prompts, workflows, and guides without backend dependencies.
Built a reproducible NotebookLM protocol used as a reference workflow for source-grounded research tasks.
Improved methodological clarity by mapping AI usage directly to research stages and quality gates.
Created a foundation for future expansion into discipline-specific research playbooks and teaching resources.
